title: Lake Mackintosh
text:
Lake Mackintosh is a <a href="reservoir">reservoir</a> with a surface area of that forms part of the <a href="Pieman%20River%2C%20Tasmania">Pieman power development</a> running north–south past Mount Farrell, adjacent to the town of <a href="Tullah%2C%20Tasmania">Tullah</a> in <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>.
Features.
Fed by the damming of the <a href="Mackintosh%20River">Mackintosh</a>, <a href="Sophia%20River">Sophia</a>, Fury, Southwell, and Brougham rivers and Mackintosh Creek, water from the lake feeds <a href="Mackintosh%20Power%20Station">Mackintosh Power Station</a> through <a href="Lake%20Rosebery%20%28Tasmania%29">Lake Rosebery</a>.
The lake was created in the 1980s and the main basin of the lake was originally a <a href="Gymnoschoenus%20sphaerocephalus">Button Grass</a> swamp prior to inundation.
Lake Mackintosh is impounded by two dams, the main Mackintosh Dam and the smaller Tullabardine Dam. The lake's deepest point is roughly deep at the base of the main dam. It is one of the larger sized water impoundments of the Pieman power scheme.
The <a href="Murchison%20River%20%28Tasmania%29">Murchison River</a> is feeds into Lake Mackintosh through the Murchison Dam, to the south. The <a href="Murchison%20Highway">Murchison Highway</a> borders the lake to the west.
The <a href="Cradle%20Mountain-Lake%20St%20Clair%20National%20Park">Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park</a> as a component part of the <a href="Tasmanian%20Wilderness%20World%20Heritage%20Area">Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area</a>, has its western boundary lying to the east of the lake shores.
